content.question: Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored. <math alttext="A T C-ase" overflow="scroll"><mi>ATCase</mi></math> is a complex enzyme involved in the production of the nucleotide <math alttext="C T P" overflow="scroll"><mi>CTP</mi></math>. <math alttext="A T C-ase" overflow="scroll"><mi>ATCase</mi></math> is composed of many subunits that are grouped into two functional domains. The catalytic domain of <math alttext="A T C-ase" overflow="scroll"><mi>ATCase</mi></math> (<math alttext="C" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> in Figure 1) contains an active site which binds two substrates (<math alttext="S 1" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="S 2" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mn>2</mn></math>) and catalyzes a chemical reaction, resulting in the formation of two products (<math alttext="P 1" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="P 2" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mn>2</mn></math>). <math alttext="P 2" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mn>2</mn></math> then acts as a substrate in the pathway leading to <math alttext="C T P" overflow="scroll"><mi>CTP</mi></math> production. The regulatory domain of <math alttext="A T C-ase" overflow="scroll"><mi>ATCase</mi></math> (<math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi></math> in Figure 1) contains an allosteric site capable of binding with the nucleotides <math alttext="C T P" overflow="scroll"><mi>CTP</mi></math> and <math alttext="A T P" overflow="scroll"><mi>ATP</mi></math>. Figure 1. Simplified model of the regulation of an <math alttext="A T C-ase" overflow="scroll"><mi>ATCase</mi></math>-catalyzed reaction (a) Describe the effect that the binding of a noncompetitive inhibitor has on the structure of an enzyme.

frqParts.text: Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored. <math alttext="A T C-ase" overflow="scroll"><mi>ATCase</mi></math> is a complex enzyme involved in the production of the nucleotide <math alttext="C T P" overflow="scroll"><mi>CTP</mi></math>. <math alttext="A T C-ase" overflow="scroll"><mi>ATCase</mi></math> is composed of many subunits that are grouped into two functional domains. The catalytic domain of <math alttext="A T C-ase" overflow="scroll"><mi>ATCase</mi></math> (<math alttext="C" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> in Figure 1) contains an active site which binds two substrates (<math alttext="S 1" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="S 2" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mn>2</mn></math>) and catalyzes a chemical reaction, resulting in the formation of two products (<math alttext="P 1" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="P 2" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mn>2</mn></math>). <math alttext="P 2" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mn>2</mn></math> then acts as a substrate in the pathway leading to <math alttext="C T P" overflow="scroll"><mi>CTP</mi></math> production. The regulatory domain of <math alttext="A T C-ase" overflow="scroll"><mi>ATCase</mi></math> (<math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi></math> in Figure 1) contains an allosteric site capable of binding with the nucleotides <math alttext="C T P" overflow="scroll"><mi>CTP</mi></math> and <math alttext="A T P" overflow="scroll"><mi>ATP</mi></math>. Figure 1. Simplified model of the regulation of an <math alttext="A T C-ase" overflow="scroll"><mi>ATCase</mi></math>-catalyzed reaction (a) Describe the effect that the binding of a noncompetitive inhibitor has on the structure of an enzyme.

(b) Based on Figure 1, explain how the binding of <math alttext="S 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mn>1</mn></math> increases the likelihood that <math alttext="S 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mn>2</mn></math> will bind.

(c) Researchers studying <math alttext="A T C-ase" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ATCase</mi></math> observed that, when <math alttext="A T C-ase" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ATCase</mi></math> is heated at <math alttext="60 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>60Â°C</mtext></math> for <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn></math> minutes, it is still able to form <math alttext="P 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="P 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mn>2</mn></math>, but the presence of regulatory molecules has no effect on substrate binding. Using the template in the space provided for your response, represent the effect of the increased temperature on <math alttext="A T C-ase" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ATCase</mi></math> structure by modifying the model of <math alttext="A T C-ase" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ATCase</mi></math> provided.

(d) Explain how the concentration of <math alttext="C T P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>CTP</mi></math> in a cell contributes to the regulation of <math alttext="C T P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>CTP</mi></math> production.
